name: py-pybind11
description:
pybind11 -- Seamless operability between C++11 and Python. pybind11 is a
lightweight header-only library that exposes C++ types in Python and
vice versa, mainly to create Python bindings of existing C++ code. Its
goals and syntax are similar to the excellent Boost.Python library by
David Abrahams: to minimize boilerplate code in traditional extension
modules by inferring type information using compile-time introspection.

dependencies.name: py-pip
dependencies.description: The PyPA recommended tool for installing Python packages.

dependencies.name: cmake
dependencies.description:
A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools
designed to build, test and package software.

dependencies.name: ninja
dependencies.description:
Ninja is a small build system with a focus on speed. It differs from
other build systems in two major respects: it is designed to have its
input files generated by a higher-level build system, and it is designed
to run builds as fast as possible.

dependencies.name: py-setuptools
dependencies.description:
A Python utility that aids in the process of downloading, building,
upgrading, installing, and uninstalling Python packages.

dependencies.name: py-pytest
dependencies.description: pytest: simple powerful testing with Python.

dependent_to.name: sirius
dependent_to.description: Domain specific library for electronic structure calculations

dependent_to.name: py-pysimdjson
dependent_to.description:
Python bindings for the simdjson project, a SIMD-accelerated JSON
parser. If SIMD instructions are unavailable a fallback parser is used,
making pysimdjson safe to use anywhere.

dependent_to.name: simsipm
dependent_to.description:
SimSiPM is a simple and easy to use C++ library providing a set of
object-oriented tools with all the functionality needed to describe and
simulate Silicon PhotonMultipliers (SiPM) sensors.

dependent_to.name: py-fenics-dolfinx
dependent_to.description:
Python interface library to Next generation FEniCS problem solving
environment

dependent_to.name: open3d
dependent_to.description: Open3D: A Modern Library for 3D Data Processing.

dependent_to.name: fenics
dependent_to.description:
FEniCS is organized as a collection of interoperable components that
together form the FEniCS Project. These components include the problem-
solving environment DOLFIN, the form compiler FFC, the finite element
tabulator FIAT, the just-in-time compiler Instant / Dijitso, the code
generation interface UFC, the form language UFL and a range of
additional components.

dependent_to.name: pygmo
dependent_to.description:
Parallel Global Multiobjective Optimizer (and its Python alter ego
PyGMO) is a C++ / Python platform to perform parallel computations of
optimisation tasks (global and local) via the asynchronous generalized
island model.

dependent_to.name: openpmd-api
dependent_to.description: C++ & Python API for Scientific I/O

dependent_to.name: py-awkward1
dependent_to.description: DEPRECATED! This package was renamed to py-awkward.

dependent_to.name: xtensor-python
dependent_to.description: Python bindings for the xtensor C++ multi-dimensional array library

dependent_to.name: py-pyopencl
dependent_to.description: Python wrapper for OpenCL.

dependent_to.name: reprimand
dependent_to.description:
RePrimAnd is a support library for numerical simulations of general
relativistic magnetohydrodynamics. If provides methods for recovering
primitive variables like pressure and velocity from the variables
evolved in quasi-conservative formulations. Further, it provides a
general framework for handling matter equations of state.

dependent_to.name: py-scipy
dependent_to.description:
SciPy (pronounced "Sigh Pie") is a Scientific Library for Python. It
provides many user-friendly and efficient numerical routines such as
routines for numerical integration and optimization.

dependent_to.name: py-torch
dependent_to.description:
Tensors and Dynamic neural networks in Python with strong GPU
acceleration.

dependent_to.name: openimageio
dependent_to.description:
OpenImageIO is a library for reading and writing images, and a bunch of
related classes, utilities, and applications.

dependent_to.name: py-projectq
dependent_to.description:
ProjectQ is an open-source software framework for quantum computing
started at ETH Zurich. It allows users to implement their quantum
programs in Python using a powerful and intuitive syntax. ProjectQ can
then translate these programs to any type of back-end, be it a simulator
run on a classical computer of an actual quantum chip.

dependent_to.name: migraphx
dependent_to.description: AMD's graph optimization engine.

dependent_to.name: xcfun
dependent_to.description: Exchange-Correlation functionals with arbitrary order derivatives.

dependent_to.name: py-spdlog
dependent_to.description:
The py-spdlog package provides a Python wrapper to the C++ spdlog
library.

dependent_to.name: autodiff
dependent_to.description: autodiff is automatic differentiation made easier for C++.

dependent_to.name: py-correctionlib
dependent_to.description: A generic correction library

dependent_to.name: py-awkward
dependent_to.description: Manipulate JSON-like data with NumPy-like idioms.

dependent_to.name: py-torch-nvidia-apex
dependent_to.description:
A PyTorch Extension: Tools for easy mixed precision and distributed
training in Pytorch

dependent_to.name: sparrow
dependent_to.description:
Sparrow: fast semiempirical quantum chemical calculations. When
publishing results obtained with Sparrow, please cite the corresponding
release as archived on Zenodo (DOI 10.5281/zenodo.3244105; please use
the DOI of the respective release). In addition, we kindly request you
to cite the following article when using Sparrow: T. Husch, A. C.
Vaucher, M. Reiher, "Semiempirical molecular orbital models based on the
neglect of diatomic differential overlap approximation", Int. J. Quantum
Chem., 2018, 118, e25799.

dependent_to.name: py-fenics-basix
dependent_to.description:
Python basis evaluation library for Next generation FEniCS problem
solving environment

dependent_to.name: akantu
dependent_to.description:
Akantu means a little element in Kinyarwanda, a Bantu language. From
now on it is also an opensource object-oriented Finite Element library
which has the ambition to be generic and efficient.

dependent_to.name: spectre
dependent_to.description:
The SpECTRE numerical relativity code. SpECTRE is an open-source code
for multi-scale, multi-physics problems in astrophysics and
gravitational physics. In the future, we hope that it can be applied to
problems across discipline boundaries in fluid dynamics, geoscience,
plasma physics, nuclear physics, and engineering. It runs at petascale
and is designed for future exascale computers. SpECTRE is being
developed in support of our collaborative Simulating eXtreme Spacetimes
(SXS) research program into the multi-messenger astrophysics of neutron
star mergers, core-collapse supernovae, and gamma-ray bursts.

dependent_to.name: py-pykokkos-base
dependent_to.description:
Minimal set of bindings for Kokkos interoperability with Python
(initialize, finalize, View, DynRankView, Kokkos-tools)

dependent_to.name: py-qiskit-aer
dependent_to.description:
Aer is a high performance simulator for quantum circuits that includes
noise models

dependent_to.name: py-onnx-runtime
dependent_to.description:
ONNX Runtime is a performance-focused complete scoring engine for Open
Neural Network Exchange (ONNX) models, with an open extensible
architecture to continually address the latest developments in AI and
Deep Learning. ONNX Runtime stays up to date with the ONNX standard with
complete implementation of all ONNX operators, and supports all ONNX
releases (1.2+) with both future and backwards compatibility.

dependent_to.name: py-httpstan
dependent_to.description: HTTP-based REST interface to Stan, a package for Bayesian inference.

dependent_to.name: arbor
dependent_to.description:
Arbor is a high-performance library for computational neuroscience
simulations.

dependent_to.name: xyce
dependent_to.description:
Xyce (rhymes with 'spice') is an open source, SPICE-compatible, high-
performance analog circuit simulator, capable of solving extremely large
circuit problems by supporting large-scale parallel computing platforms.
Xyce also supports serial execution on all common desktop platforms, and
small-scale parallel runs on Unix-like systems. In addition to analog
electronic simulation, Xyce has also been used to investigate more
general network systems, such as neural networks and power grids.
